results.title: Incident at Hawk's Hill
results.brief_description: A story based on Allan W. Eckert’s novel “Incident at Hawk’s Hill” about a shy, lonely six-year-old who wanders into the Canadian Prairie and spends a summer under the protection of a badger. Edited from the motion picture entitled “The Boy who talked to badgers”, originally shown in 1974 on the teelevision program “The Wonderful World of Disney”.

results.title: Incest: the victim nobody believes
results.creator_credit: J Gary Mitchell Film Company and J. Gary Mitchell
results.brief_description: Openly discusses the issues of child sexual abuse and helps make the public aware of the extent of this problem. Points out the impact a childhood incestuous experience can have on a victim’s entire life.

results.title: Incendio (D)
results.creator_credit: National Fire Protection Association (U.S.), Craig Johnson and Eliot Tarlin
results.brief_description: This film is based on information gathered for a joint investigation of the Joelma Building fire in Sao Paulo, Brazil in 1974 by the National Fire Protection Association and the National Bureau of Standards (US Dept of Commerce). It is a sobering and haunting account of a real-life “towering inferno” - two hours of fire, 179 dead. It contains graphic and disturbing images of people leaping to their death. However, it also shows firefighting and rescue efforts and uses animation to show how fires spread in high rise buildings. Electronic score by Robert Ceely.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Fire Protection Association (U.S.), Craig Johnson and Eliot Tarlin

results.title: Inca cola
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Geoffrey Barnes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon”.
In the sixteenth century, Spanish conquistador, Pissarro, and just 150 men overran the Peruvian Inca empire, an extremely well organised, productive empire stretching 3,000 miles, consisting of over 6 million people. Ultimately, the Spanish invasion resulted in the deaths of 80% of the Incas, with the remaining Incas condemned to serfdom under harsh Spanish landlords. Jack Pizzey visits Peru to discover what it means to be Inca today. In rural areas, he finds their descendants living and farming much as their ancestors had done, but in the cities, he finds a different story with slum-dwelling Indians aspiring to the wealth, possessions and careers of the modern world.

results.title: In your hands: hygiene in the food industry
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation and Rodney Land
results.brief_description: Highlights aspects of food handling which are the personal responsibility of the food handler. Discusses the sources of potentially hazardous bacteria and the various means by which these bacteria may be transferred to food.

results.title: In your custody
results.brief_description: This staff training film, shows custodial procedures to be followed when transferring prisoners from one place to another by train, plane, and car. It illustrates subterfuges that should be anticipated, and ways in which they may be avoided or foiled.

results.title: In which we serve
results.creator_credit: Two Cities Films, Noel Coward and David Lean
results.brief_description: In which we serve is a story of a British destroyer, the H.M.S. Torrin, from its completion to its destruction at sea by the Germans. She is divebombed in the Battle of Crete, but the survivors carry on the fight. Through their experiences are shown the ordeals, the achievements and the gallantry of H.M.S. Torrin. Stars Noel Coward, John Mills, Bernard Miles, Celia Johnson, Michael Wilding and Richard Attenborough.

results.title: In waters of the Persian Gulf
results.brief_description: A picture of life along the coasts of the Persian Gulf. Here life is a battle - a struggle for existence with the desert and with the sea. In the markets of the villages, the products of cottage industries are exchanged for the products of the sea or of the desert. But everywhere water is scarce. On the coast ships are built; ships for the trade of the gulf, for the fishermen and for the pearling industry.

results.title: In two minds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
A basic training course for all staff who deal face to face with customers in any service industry. Shows how there is a danger of misunderstanding whenever two people begin a “sales conversation”. The problem is that the assistant does not know what the customer really needs and the customer does not know all the ways the assistant can meet these needs. Demonstrates with clarity and with humour that it is the assistant’s job to resolve both sets of uncertainty. Stars John Cleese. Narrated by Philip Bond.
